newsitem.title: COTE D'IVOIRE: AT&T to join Ivory Coast phone bid.
newsitem.headline: AT&T to join Ivory Coast phone bid.

text.p: U.S. telecomunications giant AT&T has agreed to buy a 35 percent stake in an African consortium that is bidding to take over Ivory Coast's telephone company CI-TELCOM, a partner in the group said on Monday.
"We have been given the firm commitment of the world's biggest telecommunications company that it will take a 35 percent stake in Africa Bell," Ivorian investor Bergson Koffi told Reuters.
Bergson said AT&T's Director for International Programmes in Sub-Sharan Africa was due in Ivory Coast on Tuesday ahead of another round of bidding on Thursday.

AT&T's decision marked a dramatic change from its previous cautious policy on CI-TELCOM, which is heavily in debt and would need heavy investment in network and equipment upgrade by the eventual operator.
The American giant had previously been selected as management contractor in the event of the bid going to Africa Bell, a consortium until now dominated by Ivorian entities.
CI-TELCOM, with an estimated value of between $200 million to $350 million, is the most important company on Ivory Coast's privatisation programme.

AT&T's involvement, if the Africa Bell bid succeeds, would represent a major breakthrough for an American company in a traditionally French domain. Ivory Coast is the most important economy in France's former colonies in West and Central Africa.
"It is a sign of things to come," said Koffi, who is president of Ivorian cellular network Loteny Telecel. "If AT&T goes ahead other American companies will also come here."
Africa Bell made the highest offer for 51 percent of CI-TELCOM's shares during a previous bidding on December 17. Its rivals are state-owned France Telecom and Telekom Malaysia.

A columnist for Ivory Coast's official daily, Fraternite-Matin, on Monday argued in favour of Africa Bell, saying that a France Telecom or Telekom Malaysia takeover of CI-TELCOM would be like handing over the phone company to the French or Malaysian state.
Africa Bell bid 106.6 billion CFA francs ($203 million) for 204,000 shares and also agreed to pay 100 percent of an 11 billion CFA capital increase envisaged for the privatised CI-TELCOM.
France Telecom threw in a sweetener by agreeing to pay off CI-TELCOM's debt of 40 billion CFA, the bulk of that, owed to itself as a major supplier and technical partner.
Telekom Malaysia, which took over Guinea's telephone company in 1995 and looks on track to clinch a similar deal in Ghana, made the lowest offer of 82.4 billion CFA for the shares.
Industry sources said Ivory Coast's government privatisation committee found none of the offers sufficient and had called for new bids, which will be opened publicly on Thursday.

The winner will take a 51 to 55 percent stake in CI-TELCOM, the state will retain 35 percent, eight to 10 percent will be sold to Ivorian shareholders on the Abidjan stock exchange and staff will be offered one to two percent.
